'''Lainey Denay Wilson''' (born May 19, 1992)<ref name="Country Daily">{{cite web |title=Meet Lainey Wilson and Learn Some Things You Oughta Know About Her |url=https://www.countrythangdaily.com/lainey-wilson/ |website=Country Thang Daily |date=September 26, 2021 |access-date=December 25, 2021}}</ref> is an American [[country music|country]] singer-songwriter. She performed at an early age, before going to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], to pursue a career as a country performer. In 2014, she released her first album on Cupit, followed by a second on Lone Chief in 2016. Wilson secured a publishing deal and later released an [[extended play]] (EP) in 2019 which included the song "[[Things a Man Oughta Know]]". In 2020, it was issued as a [[Single (music)|single]] through the [[BBR Music Group]] and eventually reached number one on the American [[Hot Country Songs|country songs]] chart.

Wilson has received seven [[Country Music Association Awards]], including winning their top honor [[Country Music Association Award for Entertainer of the Year|Entertainer of the Year]] in 2023. She has also received a [[Grammy Award]] and six [[Academy of Country Music Awards]].

==Early life==
Lainey Wilson was raised in [[Baskin, Louisiana]], a town of 250 people. Her father, Brian, was a farmer while her mother, Michelle, was a schoolteacher. She also has a sister, Janna. She became interested in music at a young age.<ref name="Allmusic">{{cite web |last1=Deming |first1=Mark |title=Lainey Wilson Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/lainey-wilson-mn0003508331/biography |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=December 25, 2021}}</ref> Her family often listened to classic country music by [[Buck Owens]] and [[Glen Campbell]]. "Country music for me and my family, it was more than music. We lived the words to those songs," she told ''[[The Advocate (Louisiana)|The Advocate]]''.<ref name="Advocate">{{cite news |last1=Wirt |first1=John |title=With a voice recalling Dolly Parton, Louisiana's Lainey Wilson is hitting the country charts; see video |url=https://www.theadvocate.com/baton_rouge/entertainment_life/music/article_88d8504c-a141-11eb-bd3a-3f1a05f65b01.html |access-date=December 26, 2021 |work=[[The Advocate (Louisiana)|The Advocate]] |date=April 22, 2021}}</ref>

At age nine, she attended a performance of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] and was drawn to the music. "I just remember looking up there, being like, ‘Man, I wanna do that'," she recalled.<ref name="The Boot">{{cite web |last1=Ladd |first1=Olivia |title=Lainey Wilson's Road from Hannah Montana Impersonator to the Opry |url=https://theboot.com/lainey-wilson-reflects-on-her-road-from-impersonating-hannah-montana-to-singing-on-the-opry/ |website=The Boot |date=June 22, 2020 |access-date=December 25, 2021}}</ref> Wilson's father taught her a couple of chords and she was soon writing songs by her preteen years.<ref name="Allmusic"/> In 2006, she released an [[extended play]] (EP) on [[Myspace]] titled ''Country Girls Rule''.<ref name="Country Daily"/> In high school, Wilson took a job impersonating [[Hannah Montana]]. Often booking her own shows,<ref name="The Boot"/> she performed as Hannah Montana at birthday parties, fairs, and festivals across Louisiana, Mississippi, and Arkansas, even once performing for child cancer patients at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital.<ref name="Allmusic"/>

==Career==

===2011–2018: early years in Nashville and independent releases===
Wilson finished high school<ref name="Allmusic"/> and moved to Nashville, Tennessee in August 2011.<ref name="Advocate"/> She first lived in a camper trailer outside of a recording studio in Nashville. The studio owner paid for Wilson's water and electricity to help make ends meet.<ref name="Taste">{{cite web |last1=Dukes |first1=Billy |title=Lainey Wilson's Perfectly Abnormal Journey to Nashville |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/lainey-wilsons-perfectly-abnormal-journey-to-nashville-interview/ |website=Taste of Country |date=May 17, 2017 |access-date=December 25, 2021}}</ref> In 2021, Wilson explained that her early years in Nashville were difficult: "It taught me that this thing was not going to be easy. It taught me perseverance."<ref name="Advocate"/> For several years, Wilson played a variety of small shows and worked on her songwriting.<ref name="Allmusic"/> In 2014, Wilson released a self-titled album on the Cupit label.<ref name="Hollywood Life">{{cite web |last1=BrowJason |title=Lainey Wilson: 5 Things To Know AboutCountry Music's Rising Star |url=https://hollywoodlife.com/feature/who-is-lainey-wilson-4590309/ |website=[[Hollywood Life]] |date=November 29, 2021 |access-date=December 25, 2021}}</ref> It was followed in 2016  by ''[[Tougher (album)|Tougher]]'', on the Lone Chief label.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Wilson |first1=Lainey |title=''Tougher'' (CD Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=Lone Chief |date=April 8, 2016 |id=5638676569}}</ref> The project garnered an audience and made the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart.<ref name="Country Albums">{{cite magazine |title=Lainey Wilson chart history (Country Albums) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/lainey-wilson/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=December 25, 2021}}</ref> In 2018, she issued her second EP, a self-titled collection that was self-released. It led to her signing a publishing deal<ref name="Allmusic"/> with [[Sony Music Publishing|Sony/ATV]] in 2018. The same year, she also signed a management deal.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Hollabaugh |first1=Lorie |title=Lainey Wilson Joins Sony/ATV Roster |magazine=Music Row |date=March 6, 2018 |url=https://musicrow.com/2018/03/lainey-wilson-joins-sony-atv-roster/ |access-date=December 25, 2021}}</ref>

===2019–present: breakout success with "Things a Man Oughta Know"===
In 2018, Wilson signed a major-label recording contract with the [[BBR Music Group]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Nicholson |first1=Jessica |title=Exclusive: Lainey Wilson Signs With Broken Bow Records |magazine=Music Row |date=August 13, 2018 |url=https://musicrow.com/2018/08/exclusive-lainey-wilson-signs-with-broken-bow-records/ |access-date=December 26, 2021}}</ref> Her first major-label release was her third EP ''[[Redneck Hollywood]]'' (2019). Her debut major label [[Single (music)|single]] was also released in 2019: "Dirty Looks".<ref name="Billboard">{{cite web | url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/9325188/lainey-wilson-emerging-country-interview | title=Emerging Country: From 'LA' to the Grand Ole Opry, 'Dirty Looks' Singer Lainey Wilson's Dream Is Realized | publisher=Billboard | date=February 28, 2020 | accessdate=April 5, 2021}}</ref> ''Off the Record UK'' praised the EP, highlighting Wilson's songwriting and the production from producer [[Jay Joyce]]. The publication concluded by saying, "The EP is raw and real, pushing the country music genre wider than ever and bringing it back to the traditional while still reinventing it to its modern surroundings."<ref>{{cite news |title=Lainey Wilson's 'Redneck Hollywood' Is A True Representation of The Power of Women in Country Music |url=https://www.offtherecorduk.com/lainey-wilsons-redneck-hollywood-review/ |access-date=December 26, 2021 |work=Off the Record UK |date=September 14, 2019}}</ref> Wilson then received attention from [[Country Music Television]], who included her in their "Listen Up" Class of 2019<ref>{{cite web |last1=Tingle |first1=Lauren |title=CMT Listen Up Reveals 2019 Class |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1801718/cmt-listen-up-reveals-2019-class/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181218231012/http://www.cmt.com/news/1801718/cmt-listen-up-reveals-2019-class/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=December 18, 2018 |website=CMT.com |access-date=April 27, 2021}}</ref> and on their "2019 CMT Next Women of Country" tour.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Tingle |first1=Lauren |title=CMT's Next Women of Country Inspire Positive Change |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1800772/cmts-next-women-of-country-inspire-positive-change/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181114050725/http://www.cmt.com/news/1800772/cmts-next-women-of-country-inspire-positive-change/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 14, 2018 |website=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] |access-date=April 27, 2021}}</ref> She also toured with [[Morgan Wallen]] in 2019.<ref name="Billboard"/> During this same period, several of her songs were featured in the [[Paramount Network]] show ''[[Yellowstone (American TV series)|Yellowstone]]''.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sawyer |first1=Bobbie Jean |title=Songs From the Bunkhouse: Lainey Wilson on Being Featured on 'Yellowstone,' the 'Coolest Cowboy Show of All Time' |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/songs-from-the-bunkhouse-lainey-wilson/ |website=Wide Open Country |date=December 13, 2021 |access-date=December 27, 2021}}</ref>

In August 2020, the BBR label issued Wilson's next single to radio: "[[Things a Man Oughta Know]]".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Liptak |first1=Carena |title=LISTEN: Lainey Wilson's 'Things a Man Oughta Know' |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/lainey-wilson-things-a-man-oughta-know/ |website=Taste of Country |date=August 28, 2020 |access-date=December 25, 2021}}</ref> The track gained heavy media attention from sites like [[Youtube]], [[Apple Music]],<ref>{{cite web |title=3/3/21: Up Next USA Spotlight |url=https://music.apple.com/us/station/3-31-21-up-next-usa-spotlight/ra.1560228205 |website=music.apple.com |access-date=April 27, 2021}}</ref> [[iHeart Radio]],<ref>{{cite web |last1=Mastrogiannis |first1=Nicole |title=Lainey Wilson: What You 'Oughta Know' About 'Bell Bottom Country' Star |url=https://www.iheart.com/content/2021-03-05-lainey-wilson-what-you-oughta-know-about-bell-bottom-country-star/ |website=iheart.com |access-date=April 27, 2021}}</ref> [[Spotify]],<ref>{{cite web |last1=Konicki |first1=Lisa |title=Spotify Reveals First-Ever Hot Country Artists To Watch 2021 List |url=https://americansongwriter.com/spotify-reveals-first-ever-hot-country-artists-to-watch-2021-list/ |website=americansongwriter.com |date=January 28, 2021 |access-date=April 27, 2021}}</ref> and [[Pandora (streaming service)|Pandora]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Pandora Announces Country Artists to Watch for 2020 |url=https://www.nashvillenoise.com/pandora-country-artists-watch-2020/ |website=NashvilleNoise.com |date=December 17, 2019 |access-date=April 27, 2021}}</ref> By 2021, "Things a Man Oughta Know" became her breakout single, reaching number one on ''Billboard'' [[Country Airplay]] and number three on [[Hot Country Songs]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Asker |first1=Jim |title=Billboard's Top New Country Artist Of 2021 Lainey Wilson on the 10 Years Leading Up to Her First No. 1 |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/features/lainey-wilson-interview-top-new-country-artist-2021-1235005084/ |access-date=December 25, 2021 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=December 2, 2021}}</ref> It was included on her third studio album ''[[Sayin' What I'm Thinkin']]'' (2021). The disc was her first full-length album issued on BBR and contained 12 tracks.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Wilson |first1=Lainey |title=''Sayin' What I'm Thinkin'' (CD Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[BBR Music Group]] |date=February 19, 2021}}</ref> It was her second to reach the ''Billboard'' country albums chart, peaking at number 40.<ref name="Country Albums"/> The disc received positive reviews. "Beyond writing and recording songs that satisfy country music fans, she succeeds at introducing her whole self through the music," concluded ''[[Taste of Country]]'''s Billy Dukes.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dukes |first1=Billy |title=Album Review: Lainey Wilson, ''Sayin' What I'm Thinkin'' |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/lainey-wilson-sayin-what-im-thinkin-album-review/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |date=February 19, 2021 |access-date=December 25, 2021}}</ref> ''Entertainment Focus'' commented, "The rising star knocks it out of the park with her new album."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ellwood-Hughes |first1=Pip |title=Lainey Wilson – "Sayin' What I'm Thinkin'" review |url=https://entertainment-focus.com/2021/02/19/lainey-wilson-sayin-what-im-thinkin-review/ |website=Entertainment Focus |date=February 19, 2021 |access-date=December 25, 2021}}</ref>

Wilson appeared as a supporting act on [[Jason Aldean]]'s "Back in the Saddle Tour" in 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|date=May 17, 2021|title=Jason Aldean: Back In The Saddle Tour 2021 To Launch This August With Special Guests Hardy And Lainey Wilson|url=https://www.livenationentertainment.com/2021/05/jason-aldean-back-in-the-saddle-tour-2021-to-launch-this-august-with-special-guests-hardy-and-lainey-wilson/|access-date=September 2, 2021|website=Live Nation Entertainment|language=en-US}}</ref> The same year, Wilson collaborated with [[Cole Swindell]] on his single "[[Never Say Never (Cole Swindell and Lainey Wilson song)|Never Say Never]]".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Farthing |first1=Lydia |title=Cole Swindell & Lainey Wilson Join Forces On Fiery Duet, 'Never Say Never' [Interview] |journal=Music Row |date=December 2, 2021 |url=https://musicrow.com/2021/12/cole-swindell-lainey-wilson-join-forces-on-fiery-duet-never-say-never-interview/ |access-date=December 25, 2021}}</ref> The duet was released as the second single from Swindell's fourth studio album ''[[Stereotype (Cole Swindell album)|Stereotype]]'', and became Wilson's second single to top the ''Billboard'' country chart.<ref>{{cite web |last1=NA |first1=Jess |title=Cole Swindell and Lainey Wilson Reach No. 1 with 'Never Say Never' |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/cole-swindell-lainey-wilson-never-say-never-tops-charts/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |date=April 27, 2022 |access-date=May 22, 2022}}</ref> It was followed by her 2022 solo single titled "[[Heart Like a Truck]]", then the album ''[[Bell Bottom Country]].''<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Freeman |first1=Jon |title=Lainey Wilson Tames a Wild Horse in the New 'Heart Like a Truck' Video |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/lainey-wilson-heart-like-a-truck-video-1356426/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=May 22, 2022}}</ref> Wilson received a leading six nominations at the [[56th Annual Country Music Association Awards]], becoming the fourth artist to receive six or more nominations as a first-time nominee.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/awards/2022-cma-awards-nominations-list-1235135318/ | title=First-Timer Lainey Wilson Leads Nominations for 2022 CMA Awards: Full List | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }}</ref> Wilson also joined the cast of ''[[Yellowstone (American TV series)|Yellowstone]]'' in 2022, with some of her songs also being featured in the series.<ref name="Yellowstone">{{cite journal |last1=Parker |first1=Ryan |title=Lainey Wilson 'Had so Much Fun' Watching Her Acting Debut in the 'Yellowstone' Season 5 Premiere |journal=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=November 15, 2022 |url=https://people.com/country/lainey-wilson-yellowstone-so-much-fun-watching-season-5-premiere/ |access-date=4 December 2022}}</ref> She was a co-writer on the 2023 single "[[Chasing Tornadoes]]" by fellow country artist [[MacKenzie Porter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://entertainment-focus.com/2023/05/06/mackenzie-porter-releases-the-lainey-wilson-penned-chasing-tornadoes-from-her-upcoming-debut-album/|title=MacKenzie Porter releases the Lainey Wilson-penned 'Chasing Tornadoes' from her upcoming debut album|date=May 6, 2023|first=James|last=Daykin|work=Entertainment Focus|access-date=July 20, 2023}}</ref>

Wilson received a leading nine nominations at the [[57th Annual Country Music Association Awards]] in 2023, winning five including the top honor [[Country Music Association Award for Entertainer of the Year|Entertainer of the Year]]. She was the first woman to win Entertainer of the Year since [[Taylor Swift]] in 2009.

On May 9, 2024, Wilson announced that her fifth album ''[[Whirlwind (Lainey Wilson album)|Whirlwind]]'' was released on August 23, 2024.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.billboard.com/music/country/lainey-wilson-new-album-whirlwind-1235677749|title=Lainey Wilson Talks Creating New Album ''Whirlwind'' Amid Chaos: 'We Had to Cut the S–t'|author=Melinda Newman|magazine=Billboard|date=May 9, 2024|access-date=May 10, 2024}}</ref> "[[Hang Tight Honey]]" was released as its lead single to country radio on May 20, 2024.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://assets.countryaircheck.com/public/f252c1ef-8f9b-4cb6-8cd5a556923832a7/75453ba7-520f-4d3b-97d0e6f7c4c3f167/Issue-909-May-13-2024.pdf|title=Country Aircheck Weekly May 13, 2024, Issue 909|date=May 13, 2024|publisher=Country Aircheck|access-date=May 14, 2024}}</ref>

==Influences==
Wilson's musical style is rooted in country music, but also incorporates elements of [[Pop music|pop]], [[southern rock]], contemporary country and [[classic country]].<ref name="Allmusic"/><ref name="Rolling Stone 2">{{cite magazine |last1=Freeman |first1=Jon |title=Lainey Wilson Doesn't Sound Like Anyone Else in Nashville. It Helped Make 2021 Her Year |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=December 23, 2021 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/lainey-wilson-sayin-what-im-thinkin-album-1274936/ |access-date=December 26, 2021}}</ref> In describing her style, [[AllMusic]]'s Mark Deming commented, "Wilson's voice is clear and strong, with an unapologetic Southern accent, and her songs are tough but heartfelt contemporary country with an edge that has its roots in vintage Southern rock and classic rock, as well as a dash of modern-day pop."<ref name="Allmusic"/> In describing her own musical style, Wilson characterized it as "bell-bottom country", which ''[[Taste of Country]]'' called "a cross between easy listening and hard truths."<ref name="The Boot"/> Wilson has been heavily influenced by [[Dolly Parton]], paying tribute to her in the self-composed track "WWDD" (What Would Dolly Do).<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Freeman |first1=Jon |title=Lainey Wilson Looks to Dolly Parton's Example in 'WWDD' Video |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=March 26, 2020 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/lainey-wilson-wwdd-video-dolly-parton-973417/ |access-date=December 26, 2021}}</ref> She also credits [[Lee Ann Womack]] as an influence on her career and music.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sawyer |first1=Bobbie Jean |title=Rooted in Country: Lainey Wilson Says Lee Ann Womack's 'I Hope You Dance' Spoke to Her 'Big Dreams' |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/lainey-wilson/ |website=Wide Open Country |date=June 4, 2021 |access-date=December 26, 2021}}</ref>

==Personal life==
In 2022, Wilson's father, Brian Wilson, experienced severe health issues including a stroke and a fungal infection that resulted in the removal of his left eye. This all occurred while she was filming her first season on ''Yellowstone''. Wanting to be closer to him, she considered quitting the show. However, her father encouraged her to continue filming regardless of his health outlook. He eventually recovered and was seen accompanying her on the red carpet at the [[56th Annual Country Music Association Awards|56th CMA Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=DeSantis |first1=Rachel |title=Lainey Wilson Says Her Dad Is 'Doing Great' After Suffering Stroke, Losing Eye to Infection |url=https://people.com/country/lainey-wilson-says-dad-is-doing-great-after-suffering-stroke-losing-eye-to-infection/ |website=People |date=October 26, 2022 |access-date=May 12, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Giang-Paunon |first1=Stephanie |last2=Fink |first2=Larry |title=CMAs 2022: Lainey Wilson on winning Female Vocalist of the Year, walking with dad on carpet: 'A dream' |url=https://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/cmas-2022-lainey-wilson-winning-female-vocalist-year-walking-dad-carpet-dream |website=Fox News |date=November 10, 2022 |access-date=May 12, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Wright |first1=Tracy |title='Yellowstone' star Lainey Wilson almost quit the country drama before making her acting debut |url=https://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/yellowstone-star-lainey-wilson-almost-quit-country-drama-before-making-acting-debut |website=Fox News |date=April 8, 2023 |access-date=May 12, 2023}}</ref>

In late 2022, Wilson became the subject of a [[Viral phenomenon|viral trend]] that occurred on [[social media]], predominately on [[TikTok]]. A video of her performing at a concert spread very quickly on the platform. As a result of the angle of the camera and the [[leopard print]] pants Wilson was wearing, users felt the video was very flattering to the size and shape of her [[buttocks]]. The resulting trend saw users posting additional videos, pictures, and comments expressing admiration for Wilson's figure. For her part, Lainey acknowledged the trend and has largely responded to it with good humor. She made several jokes about it and also expressed hope that many people who had only heard of her because of the posts would be inspired to listen to her music and become fans.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Young |first1=Casey |title=Lainey Wilson Responds With Dump Truck Meme After Video Of Her Butt Goes Mega Viral |url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2022/12/22/lainey-wilson-responds-with-dump-truck-meme-after-video-of-her-butt-goes-mega-viral/ |website=Whiskey Riff |date=December 22, 2022 |access-date=May 12, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Young |first1=Casey |title=Lainey Wilson Reveals How She Got Her Famous Butt |url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2023/02/14/lainey-wilson-reveals-how-she-got-her-famous-butt-width-from-my-mama-the-depth-from-my-daddy/ |website=Whiskey Riff |date=February 14, 2023 |access-date=May 12, 2023}}</ref>

In May 2023, Wilson was confirmed to be in a relationship with ex-[[National Football League|NFL]] [[quarterback]] [[Devlin Hodges|Devlin "Duck" Hodges]].<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Irvin |first1=Jack |last2=Michaud |first2=Sarah |date=May 11, 2023 |title=Lainey Wilson is Dating Former NFL Player Devlin 'Duck' Hodges: Couple Make Their Debut at 2023 ACM Awards |url=https://people.com/country/2023-acm-awards-lainey-wilson-dating-former-nfl-player-devlin-duck-hodges-red-carpet-debut/ |access-date=May 12, 2023 |website=People.com}}</ref> Wilson later revealed in an interview with ''[[The Bobby Bones Show]]'' that she and Hodges had been dating for over two years prior to the public revelation.<ref>{{cite web |title=Lainey Wilson on Her Recently Debuted Relationship & New Collaboration With Dolly Parton |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7G_XozkEGWY |website=youtube.com |publisher=[[The Bobby Bones Show]] |language=en |format=video |date=June 2, 2023}}</ref>

On May 31, 2024, Wilson opened Bell Bottoms Up, a three-story bar, [[Cajun cuisine|Cajun restaurant]] and music venue, in downtown [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/lainey-wilson-bell-bottoms-up-bar-nashville-1235675429/|title=Lainey Wilson to Open Bell Bottoms Up Bar in Nashville|first=Jessica|last=Nicholson|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=May 7, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fox17.com/news/entertainment/2024-tennessee-gallery-take-a-look-inside-lainey-wilsons-bar-bell-bottoms-up-in-nashville-broadway-davidson-county-middle-tn|title=GALLERY: Take a look inside Lainey Wilson's bar 'Bell Bottoms Up' in Nashville|first=Sydney|last=Keller|date=May 31, 2024|website=WZTV}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/lainey-wilson-bell-bottoms-up-bar-opening-date/|title=Lainey Wilson Reveals New Details About Her Bar Bell Bottoms Up|date=May 21, 2024|website=Taste of Country}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://people.com/lainey-wilson-to-open-bell-bottoms-up-bar-in-former-fgl-house-bar-space-8644850|title=Lainey Wilson to Open Bell Bottoms Up Bar in Former FGL House Bar Space in Nashville|website=Peoplemag}}</ref>
